awd_titl_txt: Math for America Los Angeles: Elevating Mathematics and Computer Science Instruction through Teacher Leadership
awd_abstract_narration:
Noyce Track 3: Master Teacher Fellowships project seeks to address the problem of unequal access to quality mathematics and computer science education in high-need school districts. One reason for this inequity is a shortage of highly-effective mathematics and computer science teachers in secondary schools. This project aims to (1) improve access to high-quality mathematics and computer science instruction in secondary schools in the greater Los Angeles area; (2) cultivate teacher leaders through intensive professional development; and (3) conduct research on the relationship between teachers' participation in communities of practice and their development of teacher leadership. The project will involve collaborative efforts between University of Southern California, Harvey Mudd College, six school districts in the greater Los Angeles area, and the nonprofit Math for America Los Angeles.  

This project will fund a total of 34 Master Teaching Fellows over two cohorts to meet varying critical needs involving mathematics and/or computer science in their school. Pairs of teachers from the same school will be selected as Fellows. Fellows will create an improvement plan for their schools' mathematics and/or computer science instructional needs. They will also participate in monthly professional development meetings, summer computer science training designed by the investigators, and academic team teaching with Fellows at their school. In addition to helping teachers produce sustainable change within their departments and schools, this project will also explore effective means to support the integration of computing and mathematics in secondary instruction. In addition, this project will produce new knowledge about the relationship between teachers' participation in communities of practice, the development of teacher leadership, and the development of teachers' equitable and ambitious teaching practices. Such systemic improvements have potential to produce more equitable outcomes in STEM instruction in high-need districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary purpose of the Math for America Los Angeles (MfA LA) Computer Science Master Teacher Fellow (CS MTF) program was to address the problem of unequal access to quality mathematics and computer science (CS) education in high-need schools in the greater Los Angeles area. Supported by funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF# 1758455), the CS MTF program was developed to attract experienced and highly educated math and CS teachers to improve the teaching of mathematics in their schools and districts through a comprehensive package of training, resources, structures for collaboration, support from content knowledge experts and financial resources that, in turn, enhanced teacher practice and leadership skills. Program activities for CS MTFs included participating in a partner or team-based school site project; receiving an additional common planning period to enact school site projects; attending national conferences and monthly professional development meetings; working with other program participants at other school sites on similar problems of practice; and working toward National Board Certification.

This grant enabled MfA LA to support 34 CS MTFs at 17 different school sites. Students in over three quarters of the schools (76%; n = 13) had a high percentage of Hispanic/Latino students; all schools had over 50% of their student population identified as socio-economically disadvantaged; and 14% of students at school sites were English language learners.

Intellectual Merit

Fellow Retention. The MfA LA CS MTF program sought to retain the best teachers and help them improve their leadership skills to improve student outcomes in mathematics and CS. CS MTFs consistently reported the facilitation of community and support provided by MfA LA was one of the greatest benefits of their participation and was often reported as a primary reason Fellows attributed to remaining in the program and the teaching profession. Of the 15 CS MTFs who completed the program as of spring 2024, 93% were in the classroom in fall 2024 and 11 (73%) have continued to remain in the program in some capacity and continued their involvement in program activities.

Teacher Efficacy and Leadership. CS MTFs consistently reported an increase in their skills and ability to integrate CS concepts into their classes and sites. Their greatest reported growth was in areas related to teaching CS concepts and ability to share new knowledge with their departments, peers, and students, that in turn, led to the establishment of CS pathways and increased leadership opportunities at their schools and districts.

Effects on Students. Across five years, CS MTFs developed new courses, pathways, and site departments focusing on student access to CS curriculum and classes. CS MTFs also fostered connections with industry partners and colleges to offer student opportunities including industry mentorships, on-site field trips, and specialized certifications and class opportunities. As one CS MTF highlighted, “I would not be an AP CS A teacher let alone a CS teacher without MfA LA. Then my school would not have CS program in place. The CS classes have changed the course of students' lives and many of them are going into CS careers. That wasn't even something they considered before taking these classes in high school.” In addition, through the work and support of CS MTFs at the sites, students gained access to a variety of extended opportunities including competitive CS and robotics teams, coding clubs, honor societies, and internships with industry partners.

Broader Impacts

Supported CS MTFs provided insight into how their participation has affected others across their department and school. Most reported a positive influence in their schools, including the sharing of new information learned through the program and collaboration among colleagues. CS MTFs frequently described the opportunities to learn from other participants at monthly PD meetings and the opportunity to present in various formats (e.g., Burst Sessions, conferences) as central components in their leadership development and facilitating systemic changes within their schools and districts. As one MTF reported, “I would not be the leader that I am today without getting opportunities to lead at MfA LA PD events.” CS MTFs also reported an increase in confidence within their department through collaboration and sharing resources, including curriculum revisions and teaching strategies that were spread widely throughout departments.


Last Modified: 01/25/2025
Modified by: Darryl Yong
